summary: This is an internal email chain from May 6, 2020, discussing the status of digital evidence processing (CART) for the Epstein case. It provides an inventory of seized devices and notes that evidence from the island has not yet been entered into the CAIR system for review. The email also mentions the burden on CART resources from multiple cases, including Nygard and Ray.

persons.name: Nygard
persons.context: Mentioned as one of the cases (along with Epstein and Ray) creating a burden on CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) resources.

persons.name: Ray
persons.context: Mentioned as one of the cases (along with Epstein and Nygard) creating a burden on CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) resources.

keyFacts: An inventory of digital evidence seized in the Epstein case includes approximately 35-40 computers, 11 phones/ipads, 21 hard drives, 4 recorders, and hundreds of CDs.
Only evidence seized in New York is available in the CAIR system for review; evidence seized from 'the island' (over 20 computers/digital items) has not yet been entered into CAIR.
The email discusses the burden on the Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART) from processing evidence for multiple cases, specifically naming Epstein, Nygard, and Ray.
